fields.label_text: [Label text by Peter Thornton] Three panels of gilt leather Dutch or English; second quarter of the 18th century Movement inscribed Roger Dunster Oak veneered with elm burr, dark-stained pearwood and some ebony. Brass mounts. Carved and gilded figures Roger Dunster worked in Amsterdam Museum No. Circ. 197-1955

fields.descriptive_line:
[Leather panel] Left half of a gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.

[Leather panel] Right half of a gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with seven chinese figures between some architectural elements and a pont. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. The whole is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, and birds. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, London, ca. 1720-1770.
fields.physical_description:
[Leather panel] Left half of a gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. This panel measures in total 561 cm, and is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of 32 small compartments with flowers, birds and sometimes a chinese rock, a fan, some delftware or a flowerpot. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. All together ten chinese figures are depicted, amongst them three women, one carying a baby, are standing in a pavillion, and two men at the top carrying a lance. The panel is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of twelve small compartments with flowers, birds, and sometimes a chinese rock or an insect. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. All together nine chinese figures are depicted, amongst them one carrying a banner, one African, one hunter and a horseman, even as a dog and a tiger. The panel is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of twelve small compartments with flowers, birds, and sometimes a chinese rock or an insect. One of these compartments shows two '...' climbing on a rock. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. The panel is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of smaller compartments with flowers, birds and sometimes a chinese rock or an insect. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

[Leather panel] Right half of a gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. This panel measures in total 561 cm, and is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of 32 small compartments with flowers, birds and sometimes a chinese rock, a fan, some delftware or a flowerpot. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. All together ten chinese figures are depicted, of which three are playing a musical instument. The panel is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of twelve small compartments with flowers, birds and sometimes a chinese rock, or insects. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

[Leather panel] Gilt leather panel with a chinoiserie decoration with several chinese figures between various architectural elements. One of a set of six panels in seven parts. The panel is surrounded by a gilt leather border consisting of fourteen small compartments with flowers, birds and sometimes a chinese rock. Painted in several colours on a gilded ground, which has been punched with several different stamps. The gilded parts between the architectural elements have been punched with small lines in such a way that scrolling leaves show up, and between the compartments a zig-zag line.

fields.label: [Label text by Peter Thornton] Three panels of gilt leather Dutch or English; second quarter of the 18th century Movement inscribed Roger Dunster Oak veneered with elm burr, dark-stained pearwood and some ebony. Brass mounts. Carved and gilded figures Roger Dunster worked in Amsterdam Museum No. Circ. 197-1955 [1971]
fields.bibliography:
Lenygon, Francis, 'The "Chinese tase" in English decoration', Art Journal , July 1911, p. 193, 195.
'Also dating from the closing years of the 17th century is the example of gilt and decorated leather work (p. 195). The piece illustrated, which is one of a set which covers the entire wall space of a room, is of Dutch origin and was produced at a time when the Bavarian Republic had succeeded in absorbing this as well as nearly every other trade in which the Flemings previously excelled. Ornamented leather had become a very fashionable form of wall decoration, and no rich burgomaster's house was complete without its gilt leather room. .....'

Lenygon, Francis, 'Gilt Leather Rooms', Art Journal , September 1911, ill. opp. p. 280.
'Dutch, XVIIth century'

Lenygon, Francis, English decoration in England from 1660 to 1770, London 1914, fig. 234.
'Portion of tooled and decorated leather hangings in the morning room at Walhampton, of Chinese design, decorated in colours on gold ground. Dutch, late XVIIth century'.
fields.history_note:
A six-folded screen at Walmer Castle, Kent (Engl.Heritage).

Purchase price of £200 for a group of leather objects (museum numbers: W.14-1958, W.14A/1-1958, W.14A/2-1958, W.14B-1958, W.14C-1958, W.14D-1958, W.14E-1958). 

[Leather panel] These gilt leather panels have been made of several individual pieces of leather glued together, as usual. The extraordinary thing is, however, that those pieces were actually silvered before they were glued together, and because of the less cohesion, some fragments on the edges have been lost.

[Leather panel] These gilt leather panels have been made of several individual pieces of leather glued together, as usual. The extraordinary thing is, however, that those pieces were actually silvered before they were glued together, and because of the less cohesion, some fragments on the edges have been lost.

[Leather panel] R.A. Grove, Views of the principal seats, and marine & landscape scenery in the neighbourhood of Lymington, Lymington 1832 (n.p.): Walhampton, the seat of admiral sir Harry Neale, Bart., G.C.B. This manor was in the possession of the canons of Christchurch, under a gift of Richard de Redvers. At the dissolution of the monasteries, Henry the Eight granted it to Sir Thomas Wriothesly, created Earl of Southampton, from whose descendants it came into the possession of the Earls of Arundel, and afterwards to the family of the present owner and resident, who inherited it from his uncle, the late Sir Harry Burrard, Bart. who died, A.D. 1791, and by whom the present house was considerably enlarged.
It is situated about one mile north-east of Lymington, on the road leading to Beaulieu. The south front commands some pleasing views of the Isle of Wight and intervening Channel. The grounds were laid out nearly a century ago; ....'. J.B. Burke, Ulster King of Arms. A visitation of the seats and arms of the noblemen and gentlemen of Great Britain, London 1852-1853, Vol. I, p. 63: Walhampton, near Lymington, Hampshire. The seat of Rev. Sir George Burrard, Bart., Chaplain of the Queen, Vicar of Middleton Tyas, co. York. At one time the estate has belonged to the Arundels, from whom it was purchased by the Burrards, who have resided at Walhampton since the reign of Queen Elisabeth. ... It is uncertain when the mansion was erected. ...'Compare the hanging in Honnington Hall: English houses, Period V, vol. I, p. 270, fig. 325

These gilt leather panels have been made of several individual pieces of leather glued together, as usual. The extraordinary thing is, however, that those pieces were actually silvered before they were glued together, and because of the less cohesion, some fragments on the edges have been lost. 
This wall hanging has been analysed as part of the gilt leather cataloguing project in 1996. Eloy Koldeweij, October 1996
